DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

US President Trump tweeted it is expected that China will be buying large amounts of US agricultural products. In related news, traders noted that Chinese importers bought 600k tonnes of US soybeans for October to December shipment from the Pacific northwest. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump is prepared to keep tariffs on China and raise them if needed. (Newswires)

There were reports that US President Trump's advisers are considering an interim China deal to delay tariffs in which they are considering delaying or rolling back December tariffs in exchange for China making commitments to both IP protection and agriculture purchase. However, it was also reported that President Trump is yet to approve this, while a senior US Administration official denied this and stated that the White House is absolutely not considering an interim deal with China. (Newswires/CNBC)

US Presidential Trade Advisor Pilsbury said President Trump could do a quick deal with China but doesn’t want a quick deal and instead wants the right deal, while he added that Trump made the case that if China waits 16 months for a deal, it will be harder to get. (Fox)

US President Trump's advisors are said to be rushing to find an escape from tariff increases in the coming months and are trying to bring back the previous terms negotiated in May, according to a source. (Politico)

China Vice Premier Liu He confirmed China and US working-level officials will meet next week to discuss trade balance, market access and investors' protections. (Newswires)

China’s MOFCOM said Chinese firms have begun enquiring about prices for US farm purchases and they welcome the US good will gesture regarding the US-China trade dispute. MOFCOM stated that China and US are in communication regarding high-level discussions and the working teams will meet soon, while it added that China will roll-out supportive measures to stabilise trade at a time which is appropriate. (Newswires)

China is looking to narrow the trade negotiations with the US in a bid to break the deadlock with deputy-level Chinese trade officials planning to head to Washington next week to pave the way for the high-level meeting. Chinese negotiators are said to be making plans to boost purchases of US agricultural products, giving American companies greater access to China’s market and bolstering intellectual-property protections. (WSJ)

  • Indian Manufacturing Output (Jul) Y/Y 4.2% (Prev. 1.2%, Rev. 0.2%)

 

UK

UK House Speaker Bercow warned PM Johnson that parliament will impose more "draconian" measures if he attempts to bypass the law ruling out a no deal next month, according to Daily Mail's Political Editor. (Twitter)

The EU is preparing to grant the UK a third delay to Brexit according to a leaked resolution seen by Business Insider. The resolution, which is due to be approved by the European Parliament next week, stated that an extension should be offered in order to avoid a no-deal Brexit. (Business Insider)

EU27 Diplomats were briefed on Brexit in which Brussels officials do not think a breakthrough is imminent and stated that the British had presented no proper alternatives to the backstop. Furthermore, the EU side does not believe that ideas for alternative arrangements are adequate and officials see a return to the Northern-Irish only backstop as the only way although the UK continues to refuse this, while one politician essentially said they are not optimistic on the prospect of a deal by October 31st. (Guardian)

EU Parliament President Sassoli said existing withdrawal agreement with Irish backstop is the best solution for Brexit and that it cannot have a Brexit deal without the Irish backstop. Sassoli also stated that signals we are getting do not indicate there is any UK initiative to reopen Brexit negotiations and suggested to not forget that EU parliament will have the last word. (Newswires) 

 

EU

  • EU ECB Deposit Rate (Sep) -0.50% vs. Exp. -0.50% (Prev. -0.40%). (Newswires)
  • EU ECB Refinancing Rate (Sep) 0.00% vs. Exp. 0.00% (Prev. 0.00%)
  • EU ECB Marginal Lending Rate (Sep) 0.25% vs. Exp. 0.25% (Prev. 0.25%)

ECB cut deposit rate 10bps, introduced open-ended QE at a rate of EUR 20bln/month, eased terms of TLTRO, introduced tiering where part of banks' excess liquidity will be exempt, dropped calendar-based forward guidance and will now be linked to inflation.

  • ECB GDP forecast (Sept 2019): 2019 at 1.1% (prev. 1.2%), 2020 at 1.2% (prev. 1.4%), 2021 at 1.4% (prev. 1.4%)
  • ECB HICP forecast (Sept 2019): 2019 at 1.2% (prev. 1.3%), 2020 at 1.0% (prev. 1.4%), 2021 at 1.5% (prev. 1.6%)

ECB's Draghi said the Governing Council reiterated need for highly accommodative policy and stands ready to adjust its instruments, while there was broad agreement on forward guidance, rate cut, reinvestments and TLTRO, as well as full agreement on the need to act but more diversity of views on asset purchases and a difference of views on the severity of the outlook.

ECB’s Draghi stated ECB was unanimous that fiscal policy should become the main instrument in Europe, that the ECB will buy the same assets as it did in the past and that negative rates have side effects but have been very positive. Draghi also commented that growth risks remain tilted to the downside and noted uncertainties from geopolitics, protectionism, EMs. Furthermore, Draghi stated that probability of a Euro area recession is small but has gone up and that risk of German recession calls for a fiscal response, while he suggested incoming information indicates a more protracted weakness of the Eurozone economy and data points to moderate but positive growth in Q3 but also noted ECB scenarios do not reflect probability of a hard Brexit or trade tension escalation.

French, German, Dutch, Austrian and Estonian were among the ECB Governors which opposed the QE resumption which passed via a narrow majority, according to ECB sources. In other news, sources stated that Germany's lower-than-expected borrowing costs could create additional fiscal room of some EUR 5bln this year. (Newswires)

  • EU Industrial Production (Jul) Y/Y -2.0% vs. Exp. -1.3% (Prev. -2.6%, Rev. -2.4%)

 

FX

Turkish Central Bank Weekly Repo Rate (Sep) 16.50% vs. Exp. 17.25% (Prev. 19.75%). CBRT stated that the inflation outlook continued to improve citing a significant fall in August inflation and sees inflation beneath July forecasts, while it added keeping disinflation process on track with the target path requires the continuation of a cautious monetary policy stance and that the extent of monetary tightness will be dependent on underlying inflation. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC+ are holding discussions over whether to enhance compliance with oil cuts which could result in an effective output reduction of around 400k bpd according to a source, while it was also reported that OPEC+ Ministerial Committee have discussed Nigeria and Iraq's insufficient production cuts at their meeting. (Newswires/Tass)

Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz said Saudi will continue to overcomply with oil cuts and that the kingdom's October production will be 9.89mln BPD, while he added there is a clear readiness by OPEC+ to be responsive and deeper cut discussions will be left for the next OPEC meeting in December. Furthermore, the Saudi Energy Minister is said to be willing to continue production below 10mln BPD until year-end and exports will remain on the border of 7mln BPD. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said OPEC+ did not discuss the possibility of extending the production pact into 2020 and that it is too early for such a discussion, while he also stated that US oil output growth will be slowing down and US oil industry is struggling to attract investment to grow output. (Newswires)

Iraqi Oil Minister said September production levels will be significantly lower than in August and more cuts will follow in October, while he emphasised commitment to OPEC+ production cuts and the UAE Energy Minister said oil production volumes in September-October will be lower than in August.

IEA Monthly Oil Report maintained oil demand growth estimates for 2019 and 2020 at 1.1mln bpd and 1.3mln bpd respectively. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there are currently no plans for US President Trump to meet with Iran's President Rouhani and the US is still maintaining maximum pressure on Iran. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump reiterated criticism of the Fed citing the latest ECB 10bps cut in which he stated the ECB are acting quickly and are trying and succeeding depreciating the EUR against a very strong USD while the Fed sits. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said US President Trump is not considering payroll taxes right now but is focused on another tax cut next year and is focused on a stable dollar. Mnuchin also stated there is some demand for 50-year bond which is seriously on the table for next year and that a 100-year bond will be considered at the appropriate time, while he added it would be a good thing to expand the US's borrowing capabilities. (Newswires)

US House Judiciary Committee voted to adopt a resolution intensifying impeachment probe of US President Trump. (Newswires)

  • US CPI (Aug) Y/Y 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.8% (Prev. 1.8%). (Newswires)
  • US Core CPI (Aug) Y/Y 2.4% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.2%)

 

MARKET RECAP

Oracle (ORCL) dived on the open after the announcement its CEO would be leaving unexpectedly, with investors putting a decent earnings report in the back seat; DXC Technologies’ (DXC) CEO departure also sent the stock diving. Kroger (KR) had a choppy day of trade after beating on EPS but in its sales conference said sales improvements were taking longer than expected, it traded higher at the close. Visa (V) was at the top of Dow, catching tailwinds after closing its acquisition of Verifi following final approvals; Boeing (BA) was at bottom, paring back some of Wednesday’s optimism on 737 MAX flight return spurred by the CEO. Caterpillar (CAT) and Deere (DE) were weighing on industrials after Wells Fargo downgraded the pair, citing cyclical peaks had been reached. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) was an outperformer after receiving an upgrade at Nomura and positive comments from Jefferies. PayPal (PYPL) traded near the top of the Nasdaq 100 after Canaccord assumed the payments Co with a Buy rating. S&P 500 0.3% at 3010, Nasdaq-100 0.4% at 7917, Dow Jones 0.2% at 27185.

The TPLEX, and EGBs, were whipped about in the wake of the ECB. The initial announcement of fresh open-ended QE spiked futures; however, as participants read between the lines of the fresh stimulus, bonds pared reversed their initial move, with some desks attributing little detail of whether the ECB would add more asset classes to its QE programme, and that Draghi said the ECB is not yet ready to change the issue and issuer limits, and that EUR 20bln p.m. was a suitable pace of purchases (EUR 20bln p.m. was towards the lower end of QE estimates bare in mind). At settlement, yields were higher by approximately 6bps across the entire Treasury curve. US T-notes (z9) settled 15 ticks lower at 129-14.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 12th September 2019: ECB cuts, tiers, and injects fresh QE
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 12th September 2019: ECB cuts, tiers, and injects fresh QE

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Crude down, Dollar down

* REAR VIEW: ECB cuts 10bps, announces tiered rates, open-ended EUR 20bln p.m. QE; US announces short-term tariff delay; US CPI in-line to slightly firmer; OPEC+ JMMC fails to provide immediate action

* COMING UP: Data: US Import Prices & University of Michigan Sentiment (Prelim) Event: Moody's rating the EU & Chinese Mid-Autumn Festival Speakers: BoE's Cunliffe

 

* ECB: The landmark decision saw the ECB act on multiple fronts. The Bank cut its deposit rate further into negative territory, with a reduction of 10bps to -0.50%, leaning back on some calls for a deeper cut of 20bps. Additionally, policymakers opted to relaunch the APP at a clip of EUR 20bln p.m. from November, which at first might have disappointed the consensus view, which sought a rate of EUR 30bln p.m. However, the open-ended nature of the purchases helped assuage some of those concerns, albeit there was no change to the issuer limit that some had been looking for. Furthermore, in terms of forward guidance on rates, the next rate hike will not occur until the inflation outlook “robustly converges to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within its projection horizon, and such convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics”. As an additional sweetener, the Bank also made the terms of its future TLTRO operations more favourable. Amid concerns surrounding bank profitability in the region (alongside the prolongation of negative rates), policymakers opted to introduce a tiering system which “exempts part of credit institutions’ excess liquidity holdings (i.e. reserve holdings in excess of minimum reserve requirements) from negative remuneration at the rate applicable on the deposit facility”. Note, Draghi later leaned-back against the suggestion that such a move was carried out to protect bank profitability, and instead said the measures were imposed to help enhance the transmission of monetary policy measures.

During the press conference, Draghi noted that incoming information indicates a more protracted weakness of the Eurozone economy, with this sentiment reflected in the accompanying staff economic projections which saw 2019 and 2020 estimates lowered (2019 lowered to 1.1% from 1.2%, 2020 cut from 1.4% to 1.2%) with 2021 left unchanged at 1.4%. From an inflation perspective, the outgoing ECB chief noted that inflation was likely to decline before rising towards year-end, whilst measures of underlying inflation remain 'muted'. As such 2019-21 inflation projections were reduced with 2020 cut aggressively to just 1% from 1.4%, but it is worth noting that these projections were made prior to the unveiling of today’s stimulus measures, and thus may not incorporate how policymakers perceive 2020’s inflation prospects. Elsewhere, Draghi was careful to stress the need for fiscal measures alongside the Bank’s monetary policy efforts, with the President suggesting that the ECB were unanimous in believing that fiscal policy should become the main instrument in Europe. With regards to the overall unanimity of today’s decisions, Draghi stated that there was broad agreement on forward guidance, rate cut, reinvestments and TLTRO, whilst there was more diversity of views on asset purchases. Furthermore, there was a full agreement on the need to act, however, there was a difference of views on the severity of the outlook.

In terms of the overall take of the release, judging by the initial market reaction at 1245BST, despite just the 10bps cut, the stimulus package as a whole appeared to exceed market expectations. However, the question now is whether or not the measures taken today will be enough to help the Bank achieve its inflation goals; something which ABN AMRO have pushed-back on by suggesting that despite the open-ended nature of the QE programme, it is overall too small in size to raise inflation significantly over the next 2-3 years. Ultimately, the ECB is facing a number of headwinds external to the Eurozone and its mandate, and as such, and as concluded by Pantheon Macroeconomics, the main message from today’s ECB release is “We’re all in, but it might not work unless fiscal policymakers step up.”

* ECB SOURCES: French, German, Dutch, Austrian and Estonian were among the ECB Governors which opposed the QE resumption, according to sources, which passed via a narrow majority. President Draghi did allude to this in the presser as he stated there was a more diverse view across the board on asset purchases. Interestingly, the French also opposed QE, which follows on from commentary from Villeroy who was seemingly sitting on the fence as he questioned whether now was the right time to implement QE, albeit, now appears to have fallen onto the hawkish side of the fence for the QE decision, alongside the ECB’s notably hawkish Northern members.

* TRUMP ON FED: Following the ECB announcement, US President Trump was quick to judge, by tweeting the ECB are trying and succeeding in depreciating the Euro against a very strong dollar, whilst criticising the Fed saying they ‘sit, sit, and sit.’

* TRUMP POSTPONES TARIFFS: As a gesture of goodwill, President Trump announced that hikes to levies on imports of certain Chinese goods from 25% to 30%, that were planned for 1st October, will be delayed by two weeks (to the 15th October, and crucially, after the PRC's 70th Anniversary on 1st October). The move followed a request from China Vice Premier Liu He, and comes after the Chinese also delayed some tariffs this week while making friendly noises about buying US agriculture (though pork and soybeans remain exempted, indicating China will continue to use it as a bargaining chip ahead of the 2020 elections) -- which has provided favourable optics for Trump to take this decision -- ahead of key talks that are set to get underway in September between the two sides, ahead of face-to-face trade talks in October. Politico reported later in the session, via a source, that Trump’s advisors were “rushing” to avoid the approaching tariffs and fall back to the “90% done” deal which fell apart back in May. This echoed some reports that the advisors were looking for an interim deal to delay the tariffs, but a senior administration official denied these.

* CHINA TSF: Surprised to the upside, though overall credit growth edged lower. The data will add to calls for more stimulus, UBS said, given the rising downward growth pressure from higher tariffs and slowing domestic activities. UBS sees the government increasing policy support in the coming year, and sees the PBOC firing another 50bps worth of RRR cuts through the rest of 2019, and 100bps cuts in 2020. The central bank might also cut the new policy rate (MLF rate and LPR) by 10-15bps following the expected Fed rate cuts, UBS says, as China is now facing more disinflation (non-food CPI) or deflation (PPI) pressures than the inflationary one from surging hog prices.

* US CPI: Headline CPI rose +0.1% M/M, in line with the consensus; the core rose by +0.3% M/M, slightly above consensus, and the third straight +0.3% reading, lifting the Y/Y core rate to 2.4%, an annual rate last seen in 2008; analysts also noted that the three-month annualised rate rose to 3.4%, a 13-year high. "The outsized core increase came despite below-trend increases in primary and owner-equivalent rents, which account for 41% of the index and are likely to rebound over the next couple of months," Pantheon Macroeconomics said, "instead, the damage was done by a 1.1% jump in used car prices, the third straight hefty increase, and a 1.4% surge in hospital services costs, lifting the Y/Y rate to 2.1%, from 0.8% in July." Pantheon says it probably won’t be repeated, and the trend rate increase is still very slow. "Accordingly, we’re not ready yet to argue with conviction that the trend in the core CPI is now running at 0.3% per month. But the next few months likely will see a hit from tariffs pass-through - the first batch of tariffs on imported Chinese consumer goods were imposed on September 1 - as well as a rebound in rents, so core inflation is unlikely to fall and could easily rise further, thanks to adverse base effects from modest gains in the final few months of last year," the economic consultancy highlights that market-based inflation expectations are low.

* GERMAN FISCAL SPENDING: It was reported via sources that Germany's lower-than-expected borrowing costs could create additional fiscal room of some EUR 5bln this year, with possibly more.

* GEOPOLITICS: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said there are currently no plans for US President Trump to meet with Iranian President Rouhani and the US is still maintaining maximum pressure on Iran; pushing back on some of the progressive comments from the US made recently. President Trump, in push back to speculation that former National Security Advisor Bolton was too “hard-line”, said, “my views on Venezuela, and especially Cuba, were far stronger than those of John Bolton. He was holding me back!”

* IEA MONTHLY OIL REPORT: Maintained its oil demand growth estimates for 2019 and 2020 at 1.1mln BPD and 1.3mln BPD, respectively. This was in contrast to both OPEC’s Monthly Report and EIA’s STEO cutting their 2019 oil demand growth forecasts by 80k and 100k BPD to 1.02mln BPD and 0.900mln BPD, respectively. Additionally, both of the prior releases cut 2020 global oil demand. Elsewhere in the report, IEA sees US expansion, plus big gains from Norway and Brazil, is set to boost non-OPEC growth from 1.9mln BPD this year to 2.3mln BPD in 2020. The non-OPEC surge will cut the need for OPEC crude to 28.3mln BPD in 1H20, 1.4mln bpd below the group’s August output, the report said.

* OPEC JMMC: The new Saudi Energy Minister, Abdulaziz, said deeper cut discussions will be left for the next OPEC meeting in December; something which Oman’s Oil Minister also alluded too. In contradiction, there were earlier sources reports that members were discussing whether to enhance compliance with the cuts with an additional 400k BPD from the current 1.2mln BPD reduction, but ultimately this failed to materialise into an official announcement. Although there was discussion about lack of commitment from members including Iraq and Nigeria, with Iraq seemingly taking a more proactive stance to meet its commitments going forward. Abdulaziz said Saudi will continue to over comply with oil cuts, the Kingdom's October production will be 9.89mln BPD and remain below 10mln BPD through the remainder of the year, and there is a clear readiness by OPEC+ to be responsive. Russian Energy Minister Novak noted that OPEC+ did not discuss the possibility of extending the production pact into 2020, adding it's too early for such a discussion.

* WTI (V9) SETTLED USD 0.66 LOWER AT USD 55.09/BBL; BRENT (X9) SETTLED USD 0.43 LOWER AT USD 60.38/BBL: Crude futures trade lower again on Thursday where hopes of immediate extended production cuts at the OPEC+ JMMC meeting failed to materialise.  Analysts at Citi note that the IEA’s Oil Market Report highlighting the “daunting” prospect of a projected 2020 surplus was a headwind for the complex. Ultimately, energy markets failed to take cues from higher equity prices, but prices did drift modesty from the lows through the US session.

* US T-NOTES (Z9) SETTLES 15 TICKS LOWER AT 129-14. The TPLEX, and EGBs, were whipped about in the wake of the ECB. The initial announcement of fresh open-ended QE spiked futures; however, as participants read between the lines of the fresh stimulus, bonds pared reversed their initial move, with some desks attributing little detail of whether the ECB would add more asset classes to its QE programme, and that Draghi said the ECB is not yet ready to change the issue and issuer limits, and that EUR 20bln p.m. was a suitable pace of purchases (EUR 20bln p.m. was towards the lower end of QE estimates bare in mind). At settlement, yields were higher by approximately 6bps across the entire Treasury curve.

* 30-YEAR AUCTION: The 30-year auction high yield was 2.27%, a multi-year low, and had a chunky tail of 1.6bps, weaker than the six-auction average of 0.8bps. The B/C of 2.22x came more-or-less in-line with the average, however. The takedown was also okay, with primaries taking less than average, whilst both directs and indirects took above.

* BREXIT: The DUP have softened their stance, according to The Times, and may agree keeping Northern Ireland aligned to EU rules on agriculture, forming an all-Ireland agricultural zone, as long as the Northern Irish Assembly has a say in the development of new rules. There was also a suggestion the DUP might be agreeable to allowing single-market regulatory checks on goods being transported between Northern Ireland and mainland UK. "This is just the resurrection of the original ‘Northern-Irish’ backstop, or elements of it, that was first proposed (and objected to by the DUP) in December 2017," RBC writes, "agri-food is thought to cover only around 30% of cross-border Irish trade, however, so the EU and Ireland is likely to push for this new, 'not the Northern Ireland only backstop', to cover more sectors before agreeing to it." Elsewhere, after a Scottish court declared the government's move to prorogue parliament 'illegal', the government has said parliament will remain suspended, pending appeal. UK Speaker Bercow said later in the session that Parliament will impose more "draconian" measures if he attempts to bypass new law ruling out a no deal next month.

* FX WRAP: EUR saw choppy price action today given the ECB rate decision, on the announcement EUR weakened as they cut rates as expected and introduced an open-ended QE programme. However, as Draghi finished his presser the moves reversed with desks citing the actual size of QE, 20bln per month, being rather small and therefore expect the macroeconomic impact to be relatively modest, despite the open-ended nature. Others also highlight that money markets no longer expect the ECB to cut rates again this year. The single currency headed into Asia back above 1.1050, heading towards 1.11. TRY was the outperforming currency despite a 325bp cut as the central bank hinted towards a normalising economy with inflation levels expected to continue downwards. USD largely took its moves from the ECB and price action opposed that of the EUR, where it strengthened on the release and weakened as markets digested the moves; US CPI did little to add direction to the buck. JPY traded weaker overnight as there were further positive trade developments from the US & China, however the losses were short lived as the currency strengthened heading into ECB. As the central bank delivered the safe haven currency initially strengthened where USDJPY found resistance just above Wednesday’s low of 107.50 before paring back the moves as markets digested the central banks moves. EMFX, (ZAR,MXN) were stronger against the greenback following the ECB rate decision, BRL also aided by strong service sector growth data. XAU pared back ECB gains to end little changed.

* CBRT: The Turkish Central Bank cut rates by 325bps to 16.5%, overdelivering relative to the consensus view, which was looking for a 250bp cut. This reduction combined with the prior 425bp cut now takes rates back beneath the level before their emergency 625bp hike last year. Despite the deep cut, the Lira strengthened as the Central Bank sounded confident about the seemingly normalising economy, with inflation forecasts now expected to be even lower than forecasted in July, whilst also stating that inflation outlook is continuing to improve, citing August’s inflation data. To keep inflation tracking lower, the CBRT will continue its cautious monetary policy stance, and the extent of monetary tightening will further depend on inflation developments. ING’s analysts note that despite the further front-loading by the central bank, it should be cautious as inflation expectations are still not well anchored with high inertia, especially in services inflation, as well as global economic uncertainty due to trade tensions weighing on global growth. ING also highlights geopolitical issues still remain in Turkey, and ‘there is ongoing high dollarization and a subdued capital flow outlook’.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.3% at 3010, Nasdaq-100 0.4% at 7917, Dow Jones 0.2% at 27185

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.5%, Consumer Staples 0.3%, Energy -0.6%, Financials 0.5%, Health Care -0.1%, Industrials 0.1%, Information Technology 0.5%, Materials 0.7%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities 0.1%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Oracle (ORCL) dived on the open after the announcement its CEO would be leaving unexpectedly, with investors putting a decent earnings report in the back seat; DXC Technologies’ (DXC) CEO departure also sent the stock diving. Kroger (KR) had a choppy day of trade after beating on EPS but in its sales conference said sales improvements were taking longer than expected, it traded higher at the close. Visa (V) was at the top of Dow, catching tailwinds after closing its acquisition of Verifi following final approvals; Boeing (BA) was at bottom, paring back some of Wednesday’s optimism on 737 MAX flight return spurred by the CEO. content:
• TREASURIES: The TPLEX, and EGBs, were whipped about in the wake of the ECB. The initial announcement of fresh open-ended QE spiked futures; however, as participants read between the lines of the fresh stimulus, bonds pared reversed their initial move, with some desks attributing little detail of whether the ECB would add more asset classes to its QE programme, and that Draghi said the ECB is not yet ready to change the issue and issuer limits, and that EUR 20bln p.m. was a suitable pace of purchases (EUR 20bln p.m. was towards the lower end of QE estimates bare in mind). At settlement, yields were higher by approximately 6bps across the entire Treasury curve.
  • 30-YEAR AUCTION: The 30-year auction high yield was 2.27%, a multi-year low, and had a chunky tail of 1.6bps, weaker than the six-auction average of 0.8bps. The B/C of 2.22x came more-or-less in-line with the average, however. The takedown was also okay, with primaries taking less than average, whilst both directs and indirects took above.

subject: PREVIEW: US to sell USD 16bln in 30-year bonds at 1800 EDT/1800 BST
content:
THIS WEEK'S SUPPLY: The US Treasury will this week auction a new 3-year note (USD 38bln, Tuesday), a 10-year re-opening (USD 24bln, Wednesday), and a 30-year bond (USD 16bln, Thursday); UBS notes that that there will be around USD 26bln of cashflows (ex-SOMA) this week, including USD 24bln of redemptions and USD 2bln of coupons.

30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: Thursday's 30s auction is complicated by the ECB policy meeting, as well as the release of August CPI out of the US, both of which are on the slate for before the auction. SocGen's strategists say that, from a relative-value perspective, the 30-year sector appears rich in asset swap versus the previous 30s auction cycle. Recently, five of the six 30-year auctions have tailed, and cover ratios have been easing. "This shows that investors in general are shying away from the 30y auction," SocGen argues, "moreover, the 30-year yield reached an all-time low at end-August, and although it has since increased slightly, it is unlikely that the upcoming auction will attract favourable bidding." On the positive side, the bank notes relatively low dealers’ holdings, as well as the current 30-year trading special in repo, which might be supportive. With that said, the two aforementioned events complicate the auction, adding event risk, and accordingly, SocGen says it is neutral to slightly negative on the auction.

Daily FX Wrap: ECB and CBRT live up to headline billing, but market reviews mixed
content:
EUR/TRY

Much was expected of the ECB and CBRT in the build up to their respective September policy meetings, and in pure physical terms both delivered. In short, the former cut the key depo rate by 10 bp, enhanced TLTRO3 terms and extended the maturity from 2 years to 3, restarted QE with effect November 1 at Eur20 bn/month for an unspecified period and reinforced forward guidance by removing any calendar-based timeframe with a commitment to keeping rates at current or lower levels until such time that inflation (headline and core) and expectations are robustly convergent and stable around the target level. However, after an initial spike the Euro sold off and Eur/Usd got to within a whisker of 1.0923 ytd lows before turning full circle and more (towards 1.1069 highs) as President Draghi’s press conference and Q&A unfolded. Short covering a likely factor, but hard to justify or rationalise the turnaround bar GC division over restarting asset purchases and unanimity in the view that fiscal policy should now take the strain. In contrast, the Lira rallied and remains significantly stronger vs the Dollar on the back of a 325 bp Turkish ease vs 250-275 bp consensus as the CBRT acknowledged a marked retreat in August CPI and said the inflation outlook is now more benign than it was in July. Usd/Try is hovering around 5.6650 vs 5.7680+ at the other extreme, with investors cheering the prospect that prices may be back to target sooner and rates more normal in accordance.

USD 

The Greenback has been on a roller-coaster ride amidst increasingly bullish US-China trade headlines/reports, but mainly dovetailing the manic moves in the single currency noted above, and that were not exclusively confined to Eur/Usd. The DXY spiked to 99.109 and close to 2019 peaks before reversing sharply to sub-98.500 again with little discernible reaction somewhat mixed US data in the form of CPI and claims. However, the CNH remained on a firmer footing between 7.1085-0525 despite talk that the Trump admin may be looking at an interim deal with China quickly denied.

CHF/AUD/NZD/GBP/JPY/CAD

All off extremes against the Usd and now more narrowly mixed, but the Franc, Aussie and Kiwi remain on the front foot vs underperformance in Sterling, Yen and Loonie. Usd/Chf is back above the 0.9900 handle, Aud/Usd midway between 0.6895-60 and Nzd/Usd hovering within a 0.6410-50 range awaiting the NZ manufacturing PMI for some independent impetus. Meanwhile, Cable has reclaimed 1.2300+ status alongside the aforementioned Eur/Usd revival and maintaining vigilance on UK political/Brexit news, as Usd/Jpy pivots 108.00 and Usd/Cad holds nearer the upper end of 1.3215-1.3175 parameters against the backdrop of retreating oil prices.

NOK

The G10 laggard as crude reversed course post-JMMC with no sign of any further output cuts and US-Iran meeting speculation continued to circulate, but Eur/Nok may also have rebounded smartly from around 9.8300 to 9.9000+ on the back of the ECB and suspicions that policy action may influence the hawkish Norges Bank next week.

content: Core bonds and even the rampant Eurozone periphery have come right off the boil during the Draghi presser and Q&A on a combination of profit taking, consolidation and corrective price action, while the Euro has pared losses in contrast, with Eur/Usd back up to 1.1000 vs circa 1.0927 at one stage. Perhaps no breach of the prior 2019 base has prompted short covering in the single currency, but the yield curve is also markedly flatter and on reflection the low end 10 bp rate cut might be sinking in alongside the fact that the ECB President pointedly stated that the primary tool is now fiscal and on that issue the GC was unanimous.

subject: ECB Tiering Details: possibility of buying assets with yields below zero, multiplier to be same for all institutions
content:
• The Governing Council of the European Central Bank (ECB) today decided to introduce a two-tier system for reserve remuneration, which exempts part of credit institutions’ excess liquidity holdings (i.e. reserve holdings in excess of minimum reserve requirements) from negative remuneration at the rate applicable on the deposit facility.
  • This decision aims to support the bank-based transmission of monetary policy, while preserving the positive contribution of negative rates to the accommodative stance of monetary policy and to the continued sustained convergence of inflation to the ECB’s aim.
  • All credit institutions subject to minimum reserve requirements under Regulation ECB/2003/9 will be eligible for the two-tier system.
  • The two-tier system will apply to excess liquidity held in current accounts with the Eurosystem but will not apply to holdings at the ECB’s deposit facility. 
  • The volume of reserve holdings in excess of minimum reserve requirements that will be exempt from the deposit facility rate – the exempt tier – will be determined as a multiple of an institution’s minimum reserve requirements.
  • The multiplier will be the same for all institutions. The Governing Council will set the multiplier such that euro short-term money market rates are not unduly influenced.
  • The multiplier may be adjusted by the Governing Council in line with changing levels of excess liquidity holdings.
  • Any adjustment to the multiplier will be announced and will apply as of the following maintenance period after such decision is made.
  • The size of the exempt tier is determined on the basis of average end-of-calendar-day balances in the institutions’ reserve accounts over a maintenance period.
  • The exempt tier of excess liquidity holdings will be remunerated at an annual rate of 0%.
  • The non-exempt tier of excess liquidity holdings will continue to be remunerated at zero percent or the deposit facility rate, whichever is lower.
  • The two-tier system will first be applied in the seventh maintenance period of 2019 starting on 30 October 2019.
  • The multiplier that will be applicable as of that maintenance period will be set at 6. The remuneration rate of the exempt tier and the multiplier can be changed over time.

Market Update: Dovish reaction extends as Draghi speaks
content: The dovish reaction to the earlier ECB's rate decision and statement (details here) has extended during ECB President Draghi's press conference. Perhaps most notably, Draghi revealed the ECB's inflation forecast has been significantly lowered, to 1.2% in 2019 (prev. 1.3%), 1.0% for 2020 (prev. 1.4%) and 1.5% (prev. 1.6%). On this news, EURUSD fell from 1.0965 to 1.0928 (just above YTD lows), although has since rebound somewhat. DAX Sep' 19 futures, which had pared back from post-statement release highs, extended gains to 12471, setting fresh highs for the month of September. Meanwhile, Bund yields appear to have stabilised at around -0.64bps, although periphery bonds continue to extend gains.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • US President Trump announced he is to delay the next round of tariffs on USD 250bln of Chinese goods to October 15th from October 1st
  • China’s MOFCOM say Chinese firms have begun inquiring on prices for US farm purchases and China and US are in communication regarding high-level talks
  • OPEC+ are holding discussions over whether to enhance compliance with oil cuts according to sources, though Russian Energy Minister Novak says its too early for the discussion on extending this to 2020
  • EUR/USD remains above the 1.10 mark ahead of today’s ECB decision, having touched 1.1033 at best so far while Bunds have been volatile but are now little changed
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI & Initial Jobless Claims, ECB & CBRT Rate Decisions and supply from the US

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where US-China trade concessions fuelled the S&P 500 past the 3000 milestone and the DJIA back above 27k after China announced a tariff exemption list on imports from US, while US President Trump reciprocated by delaying the next round of tariffs on China to October 15th from October 1st. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) were higher with support seen across the trade sensitive sectors in Australia although energy suffered amid recent losses in oil, while the Japanese benchmark was underpinned by a weaker currency and following better than expected Machine Orders data. Conversely, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) were mixed despite the encouraging trade developments as some suggested China’s olive branch could be to ease pressure from its weakening economy. The US delay of the tariff increase to 30% from 25% on USD 250bln of Chinese goods was also said to have left some dissatisfied in which Global Times noted comments that the postponement does not mean a big improvement as talks remain tough, while it was also suggested that the delay is far from enough and some called for a removal of the extra tariffs. Furthermore, the downside in Hong Kong was led by the blue-chip energy names and a slump in HKEX after its recent GBP 32bln proposal for LSE which could ultimately be rejected amid doubts regarding political risk and the deal structure. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially declined amid the improvement in trade relations and after similar pressure in USTs as yields rebounded, but later rebounded as support near 154.50 held and amid the BoJ presence for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0846 vs. Exp. 7.0929 (Prev. 7.0843)

US President Trump announced to delay next round of tariffs on USD 250bln of Chinese goods to October 15th from October 1st. Reports later stated that China considers US farm imports as goodwill before talks. (Newswires/Twitter)

Senior Chinese diplomat said China cannot be deterred in anti-poverty efforts and long-term growth strategy even amid talks, while the diplomat suggested China won’t make any compromise even on promising to eliminate IP theft as it would stall growth. (Fox)

China Global Times tweeted comments from Chinese Academy of Social Sciences expert Gao that delaying tariffs may show US side's goodwill but does not mean trade talks have achieved a big improvement as talks remain tough. Global Times also tweeted comments from Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation's Bai Ming that the postponement shows trade relations are very important for both countries and that imposing tariffs is not welcome at all. Bai added that delaying the extra tariffs is far from enough and we cannot praise Trump, only by removing the extra tariffs can he show his sincerity in trade talks and more importantly, we should watch what he has done and what he will do. (Twitter)

China’s MOFCOM says Chinese firms have begun enquiring about prices for US farm purchases and they welcome the US’ good will gesture, will roll-out supportive measures to stabilise trade at a time which is appropriate. Additionally, China and US are in communication regarding high-level discussions. (Newswires)

China is looking to narrow the trade negotiations with the US, in a bid to break the deadlock, according to the WSJ

- Deputy-level Chinese trade officials plan to head to Washington next week to pave the way for the high-level meeting

US

White House said US President Trump has ruled out unilaterally indexing capital gains tax to inflation. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU27 Diplomats were briefed on Brexit this morning, Brussels officials do not think a breakthrough is imminent the British had presented no proper alternatives to the backstop, Guardian's Rankin, EU side does not believe the ideas for alternative backstop arrangements are adequate. (Twitter)

Up to 20 Labour MPs might be prepared to defy leader Corbyn and support any revised Brexit deal that PM Johnson is able to strike with the European Union, senior party figures believe. (Times)

Belfast High Count has dismissed the claim that PM Johnsons no-deal Brexit strategy would damage the Northern Ireland peace protest., LBC. (Twitter)

UK PM Johnson has offered Conservative rebels a way back into the party amid a growing split among MPs over his decision to kick them out. (Telegraph)

EU Industrial Production MM Jul -0.4% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. -1.6%, Rev. -1.4%)

-  EU Industrial Production YY Jul -2.0% vs. Exp. -1.3% (Prev. -2.6%, Rev. -2.4%)

EQUITIES

A mixed session for European equities thus far [Eurostoxx 50 +0.2%] after the trade-fuelled gains seen at the open somewhat dissipated ahead of the much-anticipated ECB meeting and US CPI data amid the risk that the Central Bank may disappoint. Sectors are mixed with energy the laggard amid price action in the complex. Turning to individual stocks, AB InBev (+3.8%) shares were bolstered to the top of the Stoxx 600 amid renewed efforts to explore an IPO of its Budweiser Brewing unit on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. Meanwhile, sources stated that LSE (Unch) is poised to reject the GBP 32bln merger offer from the Hong Kong Exchange due to concerns over political risks and deal structure. On the flip side, Whitbread (-2.7%), Lloyds (-2.0) and Accor (-3.3%) are all lower on the back of broker moves. In terms of commentary from banks, BAML sees 5% upside in European stocks over the coming 6-months due to positive EZ PMI momentum. The bank targets Stoxx 600 at 395 points for year end (~389 at time of writing).

Facebook (FB) Libra currency development will be blocked in France, according to AFP

FX

EUR - The single currency has reclaimed 1.1000+ status vs the Greenback and survived another test of technical support ahead of 0.8900 against the Pound having crossed the 100 DMA, but the Euro’s fate will ultimately depend to a large extent on how much policy easing the ECB delivers later, or what President Draghi says to address any disappointment/overexuberance in the post-meeting news conference and Q&A. Indeed, given the wide spread of options signalled by the Bank in July and clearly divergent leanings from the GC since, expectations are far more polarised than usual – see our full preview on the Research Suite. In the run up to 12.45BST and 13.30BST, a spread of hefty option expiries should keep Eur/Usd occupied and contained, with 1.1 bn at 1.0970-80, 1.5 bn at 1.1000 and 1.8 bn between 1.1040-55 vs the 1.1006-32 range so far.

NZD/AUD/CHF - The Antipodean Dollars are just outperforming the Franc at the head of the G10 ranks, as US-China trade relations continue to thaw via President Trump responding to Beijing’s goodwill gesture by delaying planned tariff hikes on Chinese goods for 14 days from October 1 to 15. However, the recently lagging Kiwi has benefited most this time, with Nzd/Usd regaining a firmer foothold above 0.6400, while the Aussie continues to face heavy resistance and cross-winds ahead of 0.6900 and over 1.0700 in Aud/Nzd. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf has retreated towards 0.9900 again, shrugging off softer Swiss producer/import prices, but aided by a broad Buck fade (DXY slipping back to pivot 98.500 compared to a 98.746 peak yesterday) and the aforementioned still defensive Eur (cross meandering from 1.0945 to 1.0915).

CAD/JPY/GBP - All on a softer footing, as the Loonie hands back more gains having failed to sustain its rally beyond 1.3150 and a further downturn in crude prices also weighs on sentiment ahead of US CPI, initial claims and more Canadian housing data. Usd/Cad has subsequently extended to almost 1.3200, in line with Usd/Jpy rising through 108.00 before waning around the 100 DMA (108.15), but holding above decent expiry interest at 107.50-60 (1.6 bn). Elsewhere, Sterling has faded some distance from recent peaks and short of 1.2350 amidst less than positive reports from the EU on the subject of a Brexit breakthrough, as the UK has still not provided a real alternative to the Irish border backstop. Cable is currently just above the 55 DMA (1.2311) circa 1.2325.

EM - Broad gains across the region in part due to the constructive US-China trade developments and the Dollar’s loss of momentum noted above, but with the Yuan also heeding another steady PBoC reference rate overnight, while the Lira has regained some composure into the CBRT after markedly underperforming of late amidst aggressive easing forecasts – again a more detailed primer is available via the Ransquawk website.

Notable FX Opion Expiries (NY Cut):

- EUR/USD: 1.0900 (751M), 1.0970-80 (1.1BLN), 1.0985-90 (475M), 1.1000 (1.5BLN), 1.1040-55 (1.8BLN), 1.1100 (1.3BLN)

- EUR/GBP: 0.8945 (500M), 0.9000 (350M)

- AUD/USD: 0.6830-40 (1BLN), 0.6860-70 (500M), 0.6880-85 (530M), 0.6900 (450M)

- USD/JPY: 107.30 (700M), 107.50-60 (1.6BLN)

FIXED

It’s tough if not remotely possible to ascertain just how much residual pre-ECB positioning has occurred or remains to be done, but suffice to say that it has been a material factor as the clock ticks down to the first of the 2 major events. Interestingly, although Eurozone bonds are all off best levels, the core is holding up better than the periphery and this is likely to be a risk-reward dynamic as there is more to lose on the margins if the GC fails to deliver or live up to lofty expectations. Meanwhile, Gilts have recoiled to a new Liffe base at 132.28 and again this may be indirectly due to the looming ECB and spread trades, but also Brexit/politically motivated as UK PM Johnson continues to face the wrath of Remain MPs and the courts for suspending parliament. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are relatively subdued and the curve remarkably flat (on the day) into US CPI, weekly claims and the final leg of this week’s supply (long bonds) after a better, though hardly strong 10 year offering on Wednesday.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures have been dipping in recent trade after a sideways overnight session, with the JMMC meeting in Abu Dhabi underway. Commentary from oil ministers has largely surrounded the need to bring compliance to 100% for all members. Sources also noted that the oil producers are holding discussions over whether to enhance compliance with oil cuts, which could result in an effective output reduction of around 400k bpd; although, this may be less than participants envisaged. Furthermore, the new-appointed Saudi Energy Minister stated that the Kingdom will continue to over-comply, whilst noting that Saudi October production will be 9.89mln BPD, up from the August level of 9.63mln BPD, which could have added pressure in the oil complex. WTI and Brent futures currently reside below 55.50/bbl and 60.50/bbl ahead of the ECB Monetary Policy decision. Elsewhere, gold prices have reclaimed the 1500/oz to the upside amid a weaker USD and nervousness that the ECB could disappoint. It’s also worth keeping in mind that President Trump delaying the China tariffs does not ultimately change the landscape in regard to sticking points, with China noting that talks remain tough and there will be no compromises on IP if it stalls China’s growth. Copper, on the other hand, has extended gains above the 2.60/lb level ahead of its 100 DMA at 2.66/lb amid continued hope that Chinese stimulus will buoy the demand side of the equation.

OPEC+ are holding discussions over whether to enhance compliance with oil cuts which could result in an effective output reduction of around 400k bpd, according to a source. (Newswires)

JMMC Comments:

- Saudi Energy Minister Abdulaziz says Saudi oil policy remains unchanged, course of action for future will be shared after the meeting, oil producers all want to achieve oil market stability and cohesiveness among producers (Newswires)

- Russian Energy Minister Novak says the joint OPEC+ efforts have a lasting and positive impact on global oil markets, confident that OPEC+ will further strengthen partnership and solidarity adds OPEC+ did not discuss the possibility of extended the production pact into 2020, it's too early for such a discussion (Newswires)

- OPEC+ Ministerial Committee have discussed Nigeria and Iraq's insufficient production cuts at their meeting, according to Tass sources

- Omani Oil Minister says the outlook for the oil market in 2020 is not very good, there are no discussions of deeper oil cuts today, states Iraq will fully comply by October and Nigeria promised to comply by October, suppl/demand is currently stable

IEA Monthly Oil Report: maintains oil demand growth estimates for 2019 and 2020 at 1.1mln bpd and 1.3mln bpd respectively

- US expansion, plus big gains from Norway and Brazil, is set to boost non-OPEC growth from 1.9 mln bpd this year to 2.3mln bpd in 2020

- Compliance with the OPEC+ agreement fell to 116% in August. In June, the US overtook Saudi Arabia to become the world’s top oil exporter.

US House of Representatives votes to ban offshore oil exploration off Florida gulf coast. (Newswires)

subject: China is looking to narrow the trade negotiations with the US, in a bid to break the deadlock, according to the WSJ
content:
• Deputy-level Chinese trade officials plan to head to Washington next week to pave the way for the high-level meeting
  • Chinese negotiators are making plans to boost purchases of U.S. agricultural products, giving American companies greater access to China’s market and bolstering intellectual-property protections
  • China has played up the need for the two countries to work together through its state media. “The tone has changed,” said Huo Jianguo, the former head of a trade-policy body under China’s Commerce Ministry
  • Via WSJ

NZD/AUD/CHF - The Antipodean Dollars are just outperforming the Franc at the head of the G10 ranks, as US-China trade relations continue to thaw via President Trump responding to Beijing’s goodwill gesture by delaying planned tariff hikes on Chinese goods for 14 days from October 1 to 15. However, the recently lagging Kiwi has benefited most this time, with Nzd/Usd regaining a firmer foothold above 0.6400, while the Aussie continues to face heavy resistance and cross-winds ahead of 0.6900 and over 1.0700 in Aud/Nzd. Meanwhile, Usd/Chf has retreated towards 0.9900 again, shrugging off softer Swiss producer/import prices, but aided by a broad Buck fade (DXY slipping back to pivot 98.500 compared to a 98.746 peak yesterday) and the aforementioned still defensive Eur (cross meandering from 1.0945 to 1.0915).

CAD/JPY/GBP - All on a softer footing, as the Loonie hands back more gains having failed to sustain its rally beyond 1.3150 and a further downturn in crude prices also weighs on sentiment ahead of US CPI, initial claims and more Canadian housing data. Usd/Cad has subsequently extended to almost 1.3200, in line with Usd/Jpy rising through 108.00 before waning around the 100 DMA (108.15), but holding above decent expiry interest at 107.50-60 (1.6 bn). Elsewhere, Sterling has faded some distance from recent peaks and short of 1.2350 amidst less than positive reports from the EU on the subject of a Brexit breakthrough, as the UK has still not provided a real alternative to the Irish border backstop. Cable is currently just above the 55 DMA (1.2311) circa 1.2325.

EM - Broad gains across the region in part due to the constructive US-China trade developments and the Dollar’s loss of momentum noted above, but with the Yuan also heeding another steady PBoC reference rate overnight, while the Lira has regained some composure into the CBRT after markedly underperforming of late amidst aggressive easing forecasts – again a more detailed primer is available via the Ransquawk website.

FIXED INCOME

It’s tough if not remotely possible to ascertain just how much residual pre-ECB positioning has occurred or remains to be done, but suffice to say that it has been a material factor as the clock ticks down to the first of the 2 major events. Interestingly, although Eurozone bonds are all off best levels, the core is holding up better than the periphery and this is likely to be a risk-reward dynamic as there is more to lose on the margins if the GC fails to deliver or live up to lofty expectations. Meanwhile, Gilts have recoiled to a new Liffe base at 132.28 and again this may be indirectly due to the looming ECB and spread trades, but also Brexit/politically motivated as UK PM Johnson continues to face the wrath of Remain MPs and the courts for suspending parliament. Elsewhere, US Treasuries are relatively subdued and the curve remarkably flat (on the day) into US CPI, weekly claims and the final leg of this week’s supply (long bonds) after a better, though hardly strong 10 year offering on Wednesday.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures have been dipping in recent trade after a sideways overnight session, with the JMMC meeting in Abu Dhabi underway. Commentary from oil ministers has largely surrounded the need to bring compliance to 100% for all members. Sources also noted that the oil producers are holding discussions over whether to enhance compliance with oil cuts, which could result in an effective output reduction of around 400k bpd; although, this may be less than participants envisaged. Furthermore, the new-appointed Saudi Energy Minister stated that the Kingdom will continue to over-comply, whilst noting that Saudi October production will be 9.89mln BPD, up from the August level of 9.63mln BPD, which could have added pressure in the oil complex. WTI and Brent futures currently reside below 55.50/bbl and 60.50/bbl ahead of the ECB Monetary Policy decision. Elsewhere, gold prices have reclaimed the 1500/oz to the upside amid a weaker USD and nervousness that the ECB could disappoint. It’s also worth keeping in mind that President Trump delaying the China tariffs does not ultimately change the landscape in regard to sticking points, with China noting that talks remain tough and there will be no compromises on IP if it stalls China’s growth. Copper, on the other hand, has extended gains above the 2.60/lb level ahead of its 100 DMA at 2.66/lb amid continued hope that Chinese stimulus will buoy the demand side of the equation.

subject: JPM thinks the recent US equity rotation from momentum into value could have legs
content:
• JPM notes the recent acceleration in the rotation from Momentum into Value, the former of which has sold off 10% and the latter gained 7% since Monday. This was one of the largest 3-day Momentum-Value rotations in over 30 years, observes the bank, who argues the move has been triggered by a combination of better than expected economic data, monetary and fiscal stimulus, easing trade tensions, stabilization in yields, all at a time when factor positioning (long Momentum and Short Value) was extreme. Moreover, while the initial part of the rotation has been largely technical (mostly down to short covering), another phase of rotation is likely to be supported by an upturn in the business/profit cycle.
  • In that regard, with renewed synchronized global monetary easing and stimulus underway, JPM says, liquidity conditions have already started to improve based on free liquidity ratio, lending activity, and credit growth. This, the bank argues, typically proceeds improved growth by roughly 6 months. Moreover, more positive impulses for growth could come in the form of an easing of US-China trade tensions; with US Presidential elections quickly approaching, JPM take the view that trade tensions should ease into 2020. As such, the bank sees the likelihood of an intra-cycle rebound in the months ahead as more plausible than that of the beginning of an outright recession.
  • If this view proves correct, the extreme divergence between Momentum/Low Vol and Value is likely to see a further rebalance. Under these circumstances, the bank defends its 2019 S&P 500 price target of 3,000 throughout this year and sees further upside to 3,200 by mid 2020 (which could come sooner if US/China trade discussions continue to improve).

subject: IEA Monthly Oil Report: maintains oil demand growth estimates for 2019 and 2020 at 1.1mln bpd and 1.3mln bpd respectively
content:
• Softer oil prices and greater petrochemical capacity helped lift July Y/Y oil demand growth to 1.3mln bpd.
  • A post-hurricane rebound in the US raised global oil supply by 530k bpd in August to 100.7mln bpd
  • US expansion, plus big gains from Norway and Brazil, is set to boost non-OPEC growth from 1.9 mln bpd this year to 2.3mln bpd in 2020
  • The non-OPEC surge will cut the need for OPEC crude to 28.3 mln bpd in 1H20, 1.4mln bpd below the group’s August output
  • Compliance with the OPEC+ agreement fell to 116% in August. In June, the US overtook Saudi Arabia to become the world’s top oil exporter.
  • Iranian oil production fell 40k bpd in August to 2.19mln bpd, exports fell 170k bpd M/M to 200k bpd
analysis_details:
• IEA maintained their oil demand growth estimates for both 2019 and 2020, in contrast to both OPEC’s Monthly Report and EIA’s STEO cutting their 2019 oil demand growth forecasts by 80k and 100k BPD to 1.02mln BPD and 0.900mln BPD respectively. Additionally, both of the prior releases cut 2020 global oil demand.
  • Its worth noting that today’s release may be somewhat overlooked given that the JMMC meeting is currently ongoing, so far, the meeting has discussed the insufficient production cuts from both Iraq and Nigeria; though focus is firmly on the stance of Saudi Arabia and Russia.

content: The core Eurozone bond has recovered poise after another downturn and just nudged up to a new Eurex high at 174.45 vs 173.87 at worst and yesterday’s 174.24 close. Easing expectations are keeping dip-buyers engaged into the eagerly awaited and anticipated September ECB policy verdict and President Draghi’s post-meeting press conference that could make up for any initial disappointment if the actual stimulus delivered falls short of ‘expectations’. However, market consensus is arguably more uncertain than ever or for a very long time given mixed messages from GC members and the various sources. Indeed, depo rate forecasts range from -50 to -60 bp, while QE calls span Eur20-30 bn per month for a year to Eur45 bn and amounts in between for 6-9 months as well, or no further asset purchases at all for now. Even the prospect of tiering is not clear-cut, but one major vendor suggests up to 30% of excess reserves could be exempt if a system is unveiled. Hence, the reaction to what unfolds looks all set to be big one way or another.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

12th September 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where US-China trade concessions fuelled the S&P 500 past the 3000 milestone and the DJIA back above 27k after China announced a tariff exemption list on imports from US, while US President Trump reciprocated by delaying the next round of tariffs on China to October 15th from October 1st. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were higher with support seen across the trade sensitive sectors in Australia although energy suffered amid recent losses in oil, while the Japanese benchmark was underpinned by a weaker currency and following better than expected Machine Orders data. Conversely, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were mixed despite the encouraging trade developments as some suggested China’s olive branch could be to ease pressure from its weakening economy. The US delay of the tariff increase to 30% from 25% on USD 250bln of Chinese goods was also said to have left some dissatisfied in which Global Times noted comments that the postponement does not mean a big improvement as talks remain tough, while it was also suggested that the delay is far from enough and some called for a removal of the extra tariffs. RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th September 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St with the S&P 500 back above 3000 and the DJIA above 27k
  • US President Trump has delayed the next round of tariffs on USD 250bln of Chinese goods to October 15th from October 1st
  • Global Times noted comments that the postponement does not mean a big improvement as talks remain tough
  • UK Operation Yellowhammer papers have revealed that public and business readiness will be at a low level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German & French CPI (Final), EZ Industrial Production, US CPI & Initial Jobless Claims, ECB & CBRT Rate Decisions, IEA Monthly Oil Report & JMMC Meeting, supply from Italy & US

12th September 2019 

·        Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St with the S&P 500 back above 3000 and the DJIA above 27k

·        US President Trump has delayed the next round of tariffs on USD 250bln of Chinese goods to October 15th from October 1st

·        Global Times noted comments that the postponement does not mean a big improvement as talks remain tough

·        UK Operation Yellowhammer papers have revealed that public and business readiness will be at a low level

·        Looking ahead, highlights include German & French CPI (Final), EZ Industrial Production, US CPI & Initial Jobless Claims, ECB & CBRT Rate Decisions, IEA Monthly Oil Report & JMMC Meeting, supply from Italy & US

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region sustained the momentum from Wall St where US-China trade concessions fuelled the S&P 500 past the 3000 milestone and the DJIA back above 27k after China announced a tariff exemption list on imports from US, while US President Trump reciprocated by delaying the next round of tariffs on China to October 15th from October 1st. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) were higher with support seen across the trade sensitive sectors in Australia although energy suffered amid recent losses in oil, while the Japanese benchmark was underpinned by a weaker currency and following better than expected Machine Orders data. Conversely, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were mixed despite the encouraging trade developments as some suggested China’s olive branch could be to ease pressure from its weakening economy. The US delay of the tariff increase to 30% from 25% on USD 250bln of Chinese goods was also said to have left some dissatisfied in which Global Times noted comments that the postponement does not mean a big improvement as talks remain tough, while it was also suggested that the delay is far from enough and some called for a removal of the extra tariffs. Furthermore, the downside in Hong Kong was led by the blue-chip energy names and a slump in HKEX after its recent GBP 32bln proposal for LSE which could ultimately be rejected amid doubts regarding political risk and the deal structure. Finally, 10yr JGBs initially declined amid the improvement in trade relations and after similar pressure in USTs as yields rebounded, but later rebounded as support near 154.50 held and amid the BoJ presence for JPY 680bln of JGBs in the belly to super-long end.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0846 vs. Exp. 7.0929 (Prev. 7.0843)

 

US President Trump announced to delay next round of tariffs on USD 250bln of Chinese goods to October 15th from October 1st. Reports later stated that China considers US farm imports as goodwill before talks. (Newswires/Twitter)

 

Senior Chinese diplomat said China cannot be deterred in anti-poverty efforts and long-term growth strategy even amid talks, while the diplomat suggested China won’t make any compromise even on promising to eliminate IP theft as it would stall growth. (Fox)

 

China Global Times tweeted comments from Chinese Academy of Social Sciences expert Gao that delaying tariffs may show US side's goodwill but does not mean trade talks have achieved a big improvement as talks remain tough. Global Times also tweeted comments from Chinese Academy of International Trade and Economic Cooperation's Bai Ming that the postponement shows trade relations are very important for both countries and that imposing tariffs is not welcome at all. Bai added that delaying the extra tariffs is far from enough and we cannot praise Trump, only by removing the extra tariffs can he show his sincerity in trade talks and more importantly, we should watch what he has done and what he will do. (Twitter) 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said the UK can manage very well without a Brexit deal and that he wants a high wage, low tax economy. PM Johnson reiterated his stance that the backstop is going to be removed and they will not accept a Northern Ireland backstop but will work for a Brexit deal, while he added the UK will leave on October 31st. (Newswires)

Up to 20 Labour MPs might be prepared to defy leader Corbyn and support any revised Brexit deal that PM Johnson is able to strike with the European Union, senior party figures believe. (Times)

UK Government said it will not publish internal messages sent about the prorogation of Parliament, despite being forced to following a vote by MPs and stated the request is "unprecedented, inappropriate and disproportionate". Furthermore, UK Operation Yellowhammer (government's reasonable worst case Brexit scenario) papers have been released which discussed public and business readiness will be at a low level and that the EU would not be nearly as badly affected as the UK, although Business Minister Leadsom will not publish the full details of the No Deal contingency planning despite being ordered to by MPs. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson has offered Conservative rebels a way back into the party amid a growing split among MPs over his decision to kick them out. (Telegraph)

UK RICS House Price Balance (Aug) -4 vs. Exp. -11.0 (Prev. -9.0). (Newswires)

ECB sources stated the ECB is to cut some growth projections with both 2019 and 2020 GDP expansion seen not far above 1%, while the bank’s projections on headline and underlying inflation is to show slow protracted rise in the coming years. Furthermore, the sources stated that forecasts suggest even with a new round of stimulus, the ECB will struggle to hit its inflation target which it has failed to do since 2013. (Newswires)

Dutch Parliament passed a motion opposing tiered rates for banks and has sent a letter to ECB's Draghi. (Newswires)

 

FX

 

The greenback was steady and held on to the prior day’s gains which were attributed to firmer than expected PPI data and a rebound in US 10yr yields, as well as the more constructive US-China trade developments. Furthermore, the greenback’s transatlantic counterparts traded lacklustre as EUR/USD languished near 1.1000 ahead of today’s ECB where there are high expectations for fresh stimulus measures but also fears of potential disappointment given that markets are heavily one-sided, while GBP/USD was also uneventful as the government continued to defy Parliament’s wishes and with UK PM Johnson steadfast in his ‘do or die’ Brexit stance. Elsewhere, USD/JPY reclaimed the 108.00 handle for the first time in over a month after the US-China concessions spurred safe-haven outflows, and CNH also strengthened from the trade developments which in turn underpinned antipodeans due to their China exposure, as well as high-beta characteristics.

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which WTI crude recouped some of the prior day’s near-3% declines that had been triggered following mixed EIA inventories and downgrade of global demand growth in OPEC’s latest monthly report, as well as a continued unwinding of the geopolitical risk premium as sources noted preparations for a potential US-Iran meeting at the UN. Focus now shift to the JMMC which will include Saudi’s newly appointed Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz, although his Russian counterpart Novak has suggested there are no plans to discuss deeper production cuts but slowing global demand for oil will be a discussion.

Elsewhere, gold prices were choppy amid an uneventful greenback ahead of today’s ECB and US CPI data, while copper prices coat-tailed on the back of the risk appetite following the improved US-China trade relations.

 

OPEC countries reportedly fulfilled the OPEC+ deal by a rate of 131% and non-OPEC countries fulfilled it by a rate 147% in August, according to sources. (Tass)

 

Oman's Oil Minister said there is an appetite among OPEC+ members for more production cuts if needed. (Argus/Twitter)

 

US House of Representatives votes to ban offshore oil exploration off Florida gulf coast. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

 

US preparations are underway for a possible US President Trump and Iranian President Rouhani meeting on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, according to sources. (Newswires) US President Trump said he is not looking at anything when asked if he would meet Iranian President Rouhani and replied we will see what happens when questioned if he would ease sanctions on Iran, while he reiterated that Iran and the US want to make a deal but it's also fine if they don't. (Newswires)

 

US President Trump previously discussed easing sanctions with advisors on Iran to help secure a Rouhani meeting at UN in which where Treasury Secretary Mnuchin voiced support and former National Security Advisor Bolton argued forcefully against it. (Newswires/Twitter)

Iranian President Rouhani and French President Macron discussed the nuclear pact over the phone in which Rouhani reiterated that the US can join talks if sanctions are removed. (Fars)

 

US

Fixed Income continued its sell-off on Wednesday, albeit more modestly, with haven demand limited on the back of US-China trade “gestures” and tentativeness ahead of the ECB meeting on Thursday. At settlement the curve had steepened, with yields higher most pronounced in the belly, the 2s10s was 1bps wider, whilst the 10s30s was 1bps narrower. The back-up in yields seen of late is not just confined to the US, it has been global. Analysts note that the rise has been led by real yields, which could be an indication that the market perceives central banks will disappointing in their largesse in the weeks ahead (ECB tomorrow, a package of measures is expected, but recent newsflow has suggested it might not be as aggressive as markets would desire, while the idea of an FOMC 50bps cut has dissipated after Powell's remarks last week). US T-notes (Z9) settled 8 ticks lower at 129-29.

White House said US President Trump has ruled out unilaterally indexing capital gains tax to inflation. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: China announced a tariff exemption list on imports from US, while US President Trump reciprocated by delaying the next round of tariffs on China to October 15th from October 1st
content:
Cathay Pacific (293 HK) - Co. reports August passenger numbers declined 11.3%, Co. will freeze hiring, lower costs and will also reduce capacity for 2019 winter season vs. Prev. expectations of capacity growth. (Newswires)

China Resources Power (836 HK) - Co. August total net generation fell 2.6% Y/Y to 17.59mln MWH. (Newswires)

HKEX (388 HK) - Co. have proposed a merger with LSE (LSE LN) for an enterprise value of GBP 31.6bln, although LSE is reportedly poised to reject the bid according to sources citing doubts over political risk and deal structure. (Newswires/FT)

Zhejiang Huafeng Spandex (002064 CH) - Co. is planning to acquire a new material firm for CNY 12bln. (Newswires)

Protests

China Ambassador to Germany said there is sufficient proof that foreign forces intervened in Hong Kong and that the reception of Hong Kong activist Wong in Berlin has sent a very negative signal for bilateral relations. (Newswires)

Hong Kong public transport network reportedly plans to cancel overnight holiday services to limit protest activity. (Newswires) 

Trade

China released a tariff exemption list for products from the US effective on September 17th in which the items on the list will not be subject to additional tariffs imposed by China on US goods as countermeasures to trade action taken by the US. Exemptions include food products and lubricants although does not list corn, soybeans or pork, while China will also consider tariff exemptions for additional products from the US. (Xinhua)

US President Trump announced to delay next round of tariffs on USD 250bln of Chinese goods to October 15th from October 1st. President had earlier commented that China made a "good gesture" with the latest tariff exclusions and quoted tweets about China’s tariff suspension which suggested China was being hit very hard with supply chains breaking up as many companies move and that it was much more expensive to China than originally thought. (Newswires/Twitter)

Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said to the US delegation in Beijing that he believes they have the wisdom to find a solution acceptable to both. (Fox Business News)

China’s Former Leading Agriculture Negotiator Guoqiang stated that China should continue to use purchases of US farm products as a "countermeasure" in US trade talks, while he added China should avoid over dependence on imports and rely mainly on domestic supplies to meet demand. (SCMP)

Senior Chinese diplomat said China cannot be deterred in anti-poverty efforts and long-term growth strategy even amid trade talks, while the diplomat suggested China won’t make any compromise even on promising to eliminate IP theft as it would stall growth. (Fox)

China permitted imports of soymeal from Argentina for the first time as it seeks to expand its import channels for farm products amid ongoing US-China trade war. (Global Times)

Other News

China is tipped to start its rate cutting road map as early as next week as an economic slowdown deepens, according to press reports citing analysts. (SCMP)

China plans to introduce measures to attract long-term stock funding and may relax restrictions on pension and insurers' stock investments. (Newswires)
